newsitem.title: ITALY: Spanish prime minister confident on EMU.
newsitem.headline: Spanish prime minister confident on EMU.

text.p: Spanish Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar, who last year ruled out any joint Italo-Spanish push for flexibility on the EMU criteria, said in an interview published on Thursday he was sure Spain would qualify on its own merits.
"I don't want a tandem with Rome," Italian newspaper La Repubblica quoted Aznar as saying in an interview from Madrid.
"Spain has to make it on its own."

Italian officials said on Thursday that Aznar was due to meet Prime Minister Romano Prodi in the northern lagoon city of Venice this weekend, but stressed it would be a private visit and had no further details.

"I want to improve the political relations between Madrid and Rome," La Repubblica quoted him as saying. "That's why I want to meet Prodi, to be able to have a long chat with him about matters that interest both our governments."
Spain and Italy fell out last year after Prodi sought assurances from Aznar that he would support a joint bid to have the tough criteria for Economic and Monetary Union relaxed.
Aznar refused and both have since redoubled efforts to be in shape by EMU's planned 1999 start.

As a result of the meeting, Prodi drew up a tougher-than-expected austerity budget to slash 62.5 trillion lire ($40.27 billion) off the 1997 deficit and has repeatedly said Italy is determined to be a founder member of EMU.
"I have no doubt that we will make it," Aznar said. ($1=1552 Lire)
